Phi Alphas, Bill Koenig
Lead In Old Gold Contest
Phi Alpha is the leading fraternity in the contest. sponsored
by Old Gold cigarettes at the last
counting Tuesday, March 19. Close
behind is the Delta Upsilon, followed by Kappa Alpha, Phi Epsilon
Phi, and Tau Alpha Omega.
In the individual race, Bill Koenig is in front. Other leaders are
John S. Wright, J. M. Harr, and
Sigmund Safier.
This contest, sponsored by the
P. Lorillard Company, will end on
April 21. It offers three prizes for
the fraternity placing the most
Old Gold wrappers in the two ballot-boxes at the postoffice and soda
fountain. For the leading group a
ping-pong table with full equipment will be given. Second and
third awards are a bridge table
with four chairs and a bridge lamp,
respectively.
For the individual winner there
is but one prize—a cash award of
ten dollars. •

Published semi-weekly from October to June, except during examination and college holiday periods by
undergraduates of the Johns Hopkins
University.

Why should this large section of
campus population remain without a
voice? You may point out that the
NEWS-LETTER is officially published
for undergraduates. But this is a
mere technicality—someone has to
pay the bills.
Perhaps we have not before elucidated our desire for non-undergraduate participation in the NEWS-LETTER.
If this was the case, we think this
appeal should convince you of our
sincerity.
Let's not limit the resources of the
NEWS-LETTER to undergraduates only.
Forget your modesty, your reserve,
or your lethargy, and make the
NEWS-LETTER a true representative of
the entire campus.

This Collegiate World

By JACK STEIN

Schenectady, N. Y.—Students

Best wishes for 1935-36 were given
the newly-elected staff of the NEWSLETTER today by Hyman M. Levin,
who was the 1932-33 editor-in-chief
of the paper as well as the 1933-34
president of the Hopkins chapter of
the Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary journalism fraternity.
Levin said:
"I want to take this opportunity

Some one of these days, I'm going
to devote this entire column to a
shameless exposé of all those pesky
Little Audrey jokes. Too many times,
courtesy forbid my making any wisecracks while hearing those insults to
a real joke, so now, by the simple
means of publicizing them, I plan to
abolish the curse from Baltimore.
Anyone having a Little Audrey joke
(?) and desiring to free themselves
of its obnoxious taint, will kindly deposit such joke (?) either at the
NEWS-LETTER office, or in Box 914.
We'll show 'em.

Jenks is continually finding it more

spread is less than their height, which
was formerly the general trait. He
feels that this change is due to athletics which are developing and

"Best Play In Five Years"

,

Zenas Sears, boss of the players,
said of the production:
"It's the best play we've had in
five years and answers all past criticisms. It is a costume play with
22 male roles, ample for all the talent
on the campus."
This second production in one year
strikes a pleasant note in our chaotic society. It is a sign of the times,
so to speak. It is the Barnstormers'
way of saying that the depression
is over, like Sehrafft's charging ten
cents instead of five for Russian
Dressing.

"And the new world will provide
a much greater amount of leisure
time. This can be either a blessing
or a curse, depending upon the manner in which it is utilized. It will
prove a decided blessing if the individual looks upon it as a creative
period to be employed in the building
of worlds other than the material—
worlds into which he may retire and
find solace and encouragement if his
But
material universe crumbles.
leisure time will be a curse if it is
merely spent in the dissipation of
human energies."

The committee will base its selections on literary and scholastic ability and attainments; qualities of
manhood, truth, courage, devotion to
duty, sympathy, kindliness, unselfishness and fellowship; exhibition of
moral force of character and of instincts to lead and to take an interest in his schoolmates; and physical
vigor as shown by interest in outdoor sports or in other ways.
The scholarship allows the student
$400 a year. The scholarships are for
two years, but are extended to include a third year where the students
excel or where the particular program of study requires an additional
year.
To be eligible for the scholarship
the candidate must be a male citizen
of the United States, and unmarried;
between the ages of nineteen and
twenty-five; and must have completed
at least his sophomore year at college.

Strachey,
internationally
,c_nown British writer and radical,
will speak on "The Menace of Fascism" Saturday, March 23, at Workmen's Circle Lyceum, 1029 East Baltimore Street. The meeting at which
he will speak will be conducted under the auspices of the League
Against War and Fascism.

The Englishman was brought to
the notice of the American people a
week ago when he was apprehended
by the State Department on charges
of illegal entry into the country. He
was forced to post bail in order to
continue his lecture tour of the country.

Phi Alphas, Bill Koenig
Lead In Old Gold Contest
Phi Alpha is the leading fraternity in the contest. sponsored
by Old Gold cigarettes at the last
counting Tuesday, March 19. Close
behind is the Delta Upsilon, followed by Kappa Alpha, Phi Epsilon
Phi, and Tau Alpha Omega.
In the individual race, Bill Koenig is in front. Other leaders are
John S. Wright, J. M. Harr, and
Sigmund Safier.
This contest, sponsored by the
P. Lorillard Company, will end on
April 21. It offers three prizes for
the fraternity placing the most
Old Gold wrappers in the two ballot-boxes at the postoffice and soda
fountain. For the leading group a
ping-pong table with full equipment will be given. Second and
third awards are a bridge table
with four chairs and a bridge lamp,
respectively.
For the individual winner there
is but one prize—a cash award of
ten dollars. •

Why should this large section of
campus population remain without a
voice? You may point out that the
NEWS-LETTER is officially published
for undergraduates. But this is a
mere technicality—someone has to
pay the bills.
Perhaps we have not before elucidated our desire for non-undergraduate participation in the NEWS-LETTER.
If this was the case, we think this
appeal should convince you of our
sincerity.
Let's not limit the resources of the
NEWS-LETTER to undergraduates only.
Forget your modesty, your reserve,
or your lethargy, and make the
NEWS-LETTER a true representative of
the entire campus.

Schenectady, N. Y.—Students

feels that this change is due to athletics which are developing and

Zenas Sears, boss of the players,
said of the production:
"It's the best play we've had in
five years and answers all past criticisms. It is a costume play with
22 male roles, ample for all the talent
on the campus."
This second production in one year
strikes a pleasant note in our chaotic society. It is a sign of the times,
so to speak. It is the Barnstormers'
way of saying that the depression
is over, like Sehrafft's charging ten
cents instead of five for Russian
Dressing.

"And the new world will provide
a much greater amount of leisure
time. This can be either a blessing
or a curse, depending upon the manner in which it is utilized. It will
prove a decided blessing if the individual looks upon it as a creative
period to be employed in the building
of worlds other than the material—
worlds into which he may retire and
find solace and encouragement if his
But
material universe crumbles.
leisure time will be a curse if it is
merely spent in the dissipation of
human energies."

The committee will base its selections on literary and scholastic ability and attainments; qualities of
manhood, truth, courage, devotion to
duty, sympathy, kindliness, unselfishness and fellowship; exhibition of
moral force of character and of instincts to lead and to take an interest in his schoolmates; and physical
vigor as shown by interest in outdoor sports or in other ways.
The scholarship allows the student
$400 a year. The scholarships are for
two years, but are extended to include a third year where the students
excel or where the particular program of study requires an additional
year.
To be eligible for the scholarship
the candidate must be a male citizen
of the United States, and unmarried;
between the ages of nineteen and
twenty-five; and must have completed
at least his sophomore year at college.
